skills.name: Convert fractions less than 1 to terminating decimals of 2 decimal places
Read a fraction on a scale where the required number is marked by a dash between two numbers

explanations.A: The numerator will only tell us about the number after the decimal if we have a denominator of 10, 100, 1000 etc. Try finding an equivalent fraction out of 100.
explanations.B: 3/20 can be changed into 15/100 by multiplying the numerator and denominator by 5. Then 15 ÷ 100 = 0.15
explanations.C: The numerator will tell us about the number after the decimal if we have a denominator of 10, 100, 1000 etc. Try finding an equivalent fraction out of 100.
explanations.D: This would be true if the denominator was 10. Try rewriting this fraction over 100 instead

explanations.A: The numerator will only tell us about the number after the decimal if we have a denominator of 10, 100, 1000 etc. Try finding an equivalent fraction out of 100.
explanations.B: This would be true if the denominator was 10. Try rewriting this fraction over 100 instead
explanations.C: The numerator will tell us about the number after the decimal if we have a denominator of 10, 100, 1000 etc. Try finding an equivalent fraction out of 100.
explanations.D: 6/25 can be changed into 24/100 by multiplying the numerator and denominator by 4. Then 24 ÷ 100 = 0.24

explanations.A: This arrow is pointing half way between 1/4 and 2/4, so that is half way between 2/8 and 4/8. That means the arrow is pointing to 3/8. Using the bus stop method to do 3 divided by 8 we get 0.375
explanations.B: Not quite. Use the fact that this arrow is half way between 1/4 and 2/4 to help you find the fraction, converting them to eighths might help. Then use division to change it into a decimal
explanations.C: I think you have found the fraction correctly but might have made a slight mistake when dividing the numerator by the denominator to get the decimal
explanations.D: Not quite, this arrow isn't pointing to 1/3. Use the fact that this arrow is half way between 1/4 and 2/4 to help you find the fraction (converting to eighths might help), and then use division to change it into a decimal

explanations.A: This number line doesn't go up in tenths so it isn't 2/10. Use the fact that this arrow is half way between 1/10 and 4/10 to help you find the fraction (making the denominator 20 might help), and then use division to change it into a decimal
explanations.B: This arrow is pointing half way between 1/10 and 4/10, so that is half way between 2/20 and 8/20. That means the arrow is pointing to 5/20. Using the bus stop method to do 5 divided by 20 we get 0.25
explanations.C: Not quite. Use the fact that this arrow is half way between 1/10 and 4/10 to help you find the fraction (making the denominator 20 might help), and then use division to change it into a decimal
explanations.D: This arrow isn't pointing to 1/3. Use the fact that this arrow is half way between 1/10 and 4/10 to help you find the fraction (making the denominator 20 might help), and then use division to change it into a decimal

explanations.A: 13 is bigger than 7, but we have 13/20 and 7 tenths that we need to compare. Try changing one of them so that they are either both decimals or both fractions to make the comparison easier
explanations.B: One way of tackling this problem is to convert 13/20 into 65/100 = 0.65. This is less than 0.7
explanations.C: These two aren't equal. Try changing 13/20 into hundredths and then into a decimal.
explanations.D: You can compare fractions and decimals. It is best to write them both as decimals to compare them

explanations.A: One way of tackling this problem is to convert 11/25 into 44/100 = 0.44. This is more than 0.4
explanations.B: 11 is bigger than 4, but we have 11/25 and 4 tenths that we need to compare. Try changing 11/25 into hundredths and then into a decimal to compare them
explanations.C: These two aren't equal. Try changing 11/25 into hundredths and then into a decimal.
explanations.D: You can compare fractions and decimals. It is best to write them both as decimals to compare them

explanations.A: The 3 and 5 don't tell us the fraction. We need to look at the difference between these numbers and how many jumps it has been split into.
explanations.B: Almost, this would have been right if the marked numbers were 3 and 4. What difference does the extra 1 make?
explanations.C: Not quite. Think about the difference between the 3 and 5, and how many jumps it has been split into.
explanations.D: The difference between the marked values of 5 and 3 is 2. This amount is shared evenly along 3 intervals, meaning that each of those intervals has a value of 2 ÷ 3 = 2/3.

explanations.A: Not quite. Think about the difference between the 3 and 7, and how many jumps it has been split into.
explanations.B: The difference between the marked values of 7 and 3 is 4. This amount is shared evenly along 3 intervals, meaning that each of those intervals has a value of 4 ÷ 3 = 4/3.
explanations.C: Not quite. Think about the difference between the 3 and 7, and how many jumps it has been split into.
explanations.D: You are almost there. Remember the denominator is how many parts it is split into

explanations.A: The difference between the marked values of 5 and −3 is 8. This amount is shared evenly along 3 intervals, meaning that each of those intervals has a value of 8 ÷ 3 = 8/3.
explanations.B: The -3 and 5 don't tell us the fraction. We need to look at the difference between these numbers and how many jumps it has been split into.
explanations.C: This would be right if it was just 3, but it is -3. Think about the difference between -3 and 5.
explanations.D: Not quite. We need to look at the difference between these numbers and how many jumps it has been split into.

explanations.A: Not quite. We need to look at the difference between these numbers and how many jumps it has been split into.
explanations.B: The -3 and 7 don't tell us the fraction. We need to look at the difference between these numbers and how many jumps it has been split into.
explanations.C: This would be right if it was just 3, but it is -3. Think about the difference between -3 and 7.
explanations.D: The difference between the marked values of 7 and −3 is 10. This amount is shared evenly along 3 intervals, meaning that each of those intervals has a value of 10 ÷ 3 = 10/3.
